modules.title: Motion & Kinematics
modules.description: Learn the fundamentals of motion, displacement, velocity, and acceleration

subtopic.title: Introduction to Motion
subtopic.content:
Motion is the change in position of an object with respect to time. In physics, we study motion to understand how objects move and what causes them to move.

**Key Concepts:**
• **Position:** Where an object is located
• **Displacement:** Change in position (vector quantity)
• **Distance:** Total path length (scalar quantity)
• **Time:** Duration of motion

**Types of Motion:**
• **Uniform Motion:** Constant velocity (zero acceleration)
• **Non-uniform Motion:** Velocity changes over time (non-zero acceleration)

exercises.question: What is the difference between displacement and distance?
options: Displacement is always greater than distance
Distance is always greater than displacement
Displacement is a vector, distance is a scalar
There is no difference between them
exercises.explanation: Displacement is a vector quantity (magnitude and direction), while distance is a scalar quantity (magnitude only).

exercises.question: In physics, what does the term "position" refer to?
exercises.explanation: Position refers to the specific location of an object in a coordinate system.

exercises.question: What is a scalar quantity?
options: A quantity with both magnitude and direction
exercises.explanation: A scalar quantity is defined by its magnitude alone (e.g., distance, speed, mass).

subtopic.title: Speed and Velocity
subtopic.content: Speed is a scalar quantity that refers to how fast an object is moving. Velocity is a vector quantity that refers to the rate at which an object changes its position.

subtopic.title: Acceleration
subtopic.content: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with time. It is a vector quantity.

subtopic.title: Equations of Motion
subtopic.content: The equations of motion describe the behavior of a physical system in terms of its motion as a function of time.

modules.title: Forces & Dynamics
modules.description: Understand Newton's laws and how forces affect motion

subtopic.title: Newton's First Law
subtopic.content: An object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.

exercises.question: What is Newton's First Law also known as?
exercises.explanation: Newton's First Law is also called the Law of Inertia.
